basics.name: Euijun Chung
basics.label: CS PhD Student
basics.summary: Euijun Chung is a second-year CS PhD student at Georgia Tech, focusing on GPU architecture and simulations. His research interests lie on cycle-level GPU simulation and performance modeling, GPU memory safety, GPU + SSD architecture co-design, and distributed workloads on Multi-GPU systems.

work.name: AMD Research and Advanced Development (RAD)
work.summary: Optimizing LLM training and inference on future chiplet-based GPU architectures.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

courses: Cycle-level GPU simulation and performance modeling

education.institution: Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST)
education.studyType: BS in Electrical Engineering and Mathematics
courses: Two-year leave for mandatory military service.

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

references.name: Hyesoon Kim
references.reference: Primary advisor at Georgia Tech. Expert in GPU architecture and simulation.

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
